body_html:
A few comments:

  1. tf.contrib.distributions.Bernoulli is not a Tensor. If it has a registered conversion to a Tensor then your code will be fine in that respect, but if not it should throw a graph-build error.
  2. The tensor target_prob represents "Target class proportions in batch". It should be a decimal number representing the target fraction per class. For example, if you have 3 classes, a 1-D Tensor with 3 elements would be acceptable. Its values could change each run of the graph, and it could take values like [.3, .4, .3], [.2, .7, .1], etc (note that these are all valid probability distributions).

Does that answer your question?

The tensor target_prob represents "Target class proportions in batch". It should be a decimal number representing the target fraction per class. For example, if you have 3 classes, a 1-D Tensor with 3 elements would be acceptable. Its values could change each run of the graph, and it could take values like [.3, .4, .3], [.2, .7, .1], etc (note that these are all valid probability distributions).

Does that answer your question?
body:
A few comments:
1) `tf.contrib.distributions.Bernoulli` is not a Tensor. If it has a registered conversion to a Tensor then your code will be fine in that respect, but if not it should throw a graph-build error.
2) The tensor `target_prob` represents "Target class proportions in batch". It should be a decimal number representing the target fraction per class. For example, if you have 3 classes, a 1-D Tensor with 3 elements would be acceptable. Its values could change each run of the graph, and it could take values like [.3, .4, .3], [.2, .7, .1], etc (note that these are all valid probability distributions).

Does that answer your question?
